conclusion: Understanding the original setup with metal rod M rotating with angular velocity ω₀ in magnetic field B₀, voltmeter V reads U₀.
Applying Faraday's Law of Induction: emf (ℰ) = B ⋅ v ⋅ L.
The linear velocity v of the end of the rod M is related to the angular velocity ω by v = ω ⋅ r.
Substituting known values for original setup: ℰ = B₀ ⋅ (ω₀ ⋅ r) ⋅ L, U₀ = B₀ ⋅ ω₀ ⋅ r ⋅ L.
New setup with modified magnetic field nB₀ and voltmeter reads mU₀.
Applying Faraday's Law again: ℰ_new = nB₀ ⋅ (ω_new ⋅ r) ⋅ L, mU₀ = nB₀ ⋅ ω_new ⋅ r ⋅ L.
Using relationship from original setup: m(B₀ ⋅ ω₀ ⋅ r ⋅ L) = n(B₀ ⋅ ω_new ⋅ r ⋅ L).
Cancel out common terms: mU₀ = nU₀ ⋅ ω_new / ω₀.
Final answer: The new angular velocity ω_new should be (m/n) ⋅ ω₀.
